lenders.name: Southern Maryland Woman
lenders.loan_because:
Whether you are a small business owner in Washington, DC, or the owner of a village grocery store in Latin America or Africa, entrepeneurs face the same challenges no matter where they live, or what goods/services they provide. As a fellow entrepeneur  we understand that money is simply a necessary tool every business needs to grow. If one compares business to farming where one begins by preparing the soil, planting the seeds etc., money is the fertilizer. 
Entrepeneurs are by nature committed, courageous, and creative, and help others in the process of operating their own businesses. Assisting other individuals to become self sufficient is much more meaningful than simply giving money which creates dependence rather than freedom.
lenders.occupational_info:
As publishers of "THE SOUTHERN MARYLAND WOMAN", we recognize the important responsibility we have to our readers and the entire community. We provide empowering information, education and resources to women to help them make the best and most informed decisions for themselves and those they love. We publish informative, objective, and educational articles written by local professionals and business owners on a variety of topics of interest to women of all ages, backgrounds, and ethnicity.  Lastly 
we are committed to supporting non-profit and charitable organizations who share our mission - Improving the lives of women and their families through education.

lenders.name: Rosa
lenders.loan_because: I care!

lenders.name: Samantha
lenders.loan_because: My father gave my sister and me gift certificates to Kiva in Christmas of 2007 (I was 15 at the time) and asked us to give back. He wanted so desperately to instill in his children the generosity that his parents instilled in him. He never knew that I already wanted to be just like him, and wanted to help people the way he did. He passed away from complications associated with brain cancer in 2009. He would never want to be connected to any of my donations on Kiva--he believed that giving wasn't from the heart if you gained notoriety for it--but every time I lend, I think of everything he taught me. Always will.

"Mom, wherever there's a cop beatin' a guy
Wherever a hungry newborn baby cries
Where there's a fight 'gainst the blood and hatred in the air
Look for me Mom I'll be there
Wherever there's somebody fightin' for a place to stand
Or decent job or a helpin' hand
Wherever somebody's strugglin' to be free
Look in their eyes Mom you'll see me."

lenders.name: Teri
lenders.loan_because:
May God bless you with discomfort -- 
At easy answers, half-truths, and superficial relationships 
So that you may live deep within your heart. 

May God bless you with anger -- 
At injustice, oppression, and exploitation of people, 
So that you may work for justice, freedom and peace. 

May God bless you with tears -- 
To shed for those who suffer pain, rejection, hunger and war, 
So that you may reach out your hand to comfort them 
To turn their pain into joy. 

And may God bless you with foolishness -- 
To believe that you can make a difference in the world, 
So that you can do what others claim cannot be done 
To bring justice and kindness to all our children, and the poor. 

Amen.
lenders.occupational_info:
My goal is to fund 1 Kiva loan a month for a year.  In addition to that, all repayments will be turned back into new loans.  I'm excited to see what my investment of $300 will do over the years!  

The above was written in Jan 2009.  It is now May 2012... those 12 loans totalling $300 have turned into 39 loans totalling $975!!

"You know, there's a lot of talk in this country about the federal deficit. But I think we should talk more about our empathy deficit -- the ability to put ourselves in someone else's shoes; to see the world through the eyes of those who are different from us -- the child who's hungry, the steelworker who's been laid-off, the family who lost the entire life they built together when the storm came to town. When you think like this -- when you choose to broaden your ambit of concern and empathize with the plight of others, whether they are close friends or distant strangers -- it becomes harder not to act; harder not to help."  
 -- Barack Obama

lenders.occupational_info:
BEACON OF HOPE UGANDA
Registration No. MKN/CBO 082/2008




Concept Paper/Proposal for:
Income Generation Initiatives: Candle Making
Mukono, Uganda
















Friday September 26th 2008
Isaac Ssamba
Chairman, Beacon of Hope Uganda, 
tel. +256753216892 / beaconyouths@yahoo.com
 
1. Project Summary 

Project Title - Income Generating Initiatives: Candle Making
Budget: US $ 1304
Submitted - Friday September 26th 2008
Organization - Beacon of Hope Uganda
Chairman: Isaac Ssamba
Tel: +256753216892
beaconyouths@yahoo.com


2. Problem Statement/Justification

Without careful planning and implementation of income generating initiatives the likelihood for Mukono to become a slum is possible. The population density in Mukono is 175.7 people per km², 29.5% higher than the national average and the rate of urbanization in Mukono is 25.3 compared the national average of 12.27. Many of the youths age 14-19 are out of school and unable to afford school fees. The local streets witness a flood of youths whom scrape by for a means to live. Some youths often resort to illegal activities like joining gangs in order to retain a small income for food. Beacon of Hope looks to provide these youths with the opportunity to earn some money part time and teach them to utilize these funds for education either in academics or vocational training. This will help alleviate them from poverty, empower their minds and boost their self confidence to help them to create positives futures for themselves.

3. Project Description

This income generating initiative will look to empower youths with the opportunity to work part time with our organization in the particular activity of candle making. The project will look towards targeting youths whom are unable to afford school fees or life’s basic necessities. The expected results look to achieve a higher ratio of youths between the ages of 14-19 capable to afford food, school fees or further vocational training. These youths, the primary beneficiaries, would be reaping the profits of a encouraging project focused principally on their lives. Instead of looking on the street for work the primary beneficiaries, will be given the opportunity to work with members of the community and Beacon of Hope Uganda in order to establish a small income. The beneficiaries will have the opportunity to get off the streets and establish themselves as trained candle makers. This project will also look to encourage youths to save and utilize their resources to go and learn other trade works either through apprenticeships or vocational schools. The beneficiaries involved with this project will learn important marketing skills and will become well educated on the benefits of learning market networks. This will increase their resources and means to make a living as they learn other skills throughout their lives. By showing these youths a productive, effective and honest way to earn a small income it will boost their self confidence and make them eager to learn how to create an advantageous future for themselves

4. Organizational Experience/Capacity

Although our organization is young (2006), the exuberance and potential within Beacon of Hope is elevated by the individuals whom comprise the organization. Well educated and informed the members look to empower youths and enable them with the opportunities to exceed and experience a lively and optimistic life experience. The members of Beacon of Hope have had past experiences as candle makers and are able and willing to pass that experience down to the youths in Mukono. Our headquarters will be used as the training and construction center for this activity and our candle making professionals will be present teaching the youths during several training seminars. Since 2006 Beacon of Hope has generated many genuine relationships with community members around Mukono. We will use this network and look to expand it when the time comes to initiate the selling phase of this program.

5. Coordination

Beacon of Hope has recently held several community meetings throughout Mukono and has received positive feedback concerning such IGI’s like candle making. Many community members are willing to help and participate with youths in aiding them to learn how to make superb candles to be sold on the market or teach the youth’s ways to access the markets and make valuable market networks. We also look to collaborate with local ministries and governments in order to help establish the project in terms of funding and possibly create more programs like this that would benefit the over abundance of disadvantaged youths in Mukono.

6. Strength and Innovation

We look to initiate multiple innovative and unique programs to help empower the distressed youths in Mukono. Our expertise and well designed initiatives will be sustainable for the beneficiaries and provide them with a small income at which they could use for school fees or other important life necessities. Beacon of Hope Uganda has chosen candle making because of the need for them. Not only are they effective during power shortages but they will also be a good instrument to repel mosquitoes as each candle will have mosquito repellant added into its mixture of dye and wax. The members of Beacon of Hope have already been trained as candle makers and are looking to pass on the knowledge and expertise to youths throughout Mukono. Sectors of the market we look to target will be churches as well as private schools that can afford to buy candles for their dormitories. The students will also be encouraged to find their own avenue in the local market with guidance from Beacon of Hope and members from the community.  

 
7. Budget

Raw Materials  Quantity Cost
Wax – refined 200 kg US $ 447
Candle Wick 8kg roll US $ 180
Satiric acid powder 10kg US $ 37
2 mould machines 50 pieces US $ 387
Colors oil Soluble 2kg US $ 80
Mosquito repellants 1500mls US $ 34
Administrative (%) 5% of project cost US $ 59
Totals US $ 1304


 
Level of Objectives
Objectively Verifiable Indicators – Indicators and targets Means of Verification (Data sources) Assumptions and Risks
Impact:
Youth empowerment, education and trade knowledge increases and poverty eradication decreases. 1. 70% improved levels of well being.
2. 70% of beneficiaries report higher self esteem after leaving program to work elsewhere.
 1. Surveys.
2. Questionnaires.
3. Organizational report.
4. Interviews with beneficiaries. 1. Beneficiaries encourage other disadvantaged youths in the community to partake in similar programs.
Outcomes
1. Increased income generation and improved livelihoods among youths in Mukono.
2. Less youths on the street, less crime.
3. Youths self esteem rises, eager to learn more. 1. 70% increase in beneficiaries reporting better living standards.
2. 70% of beneficiaries utilizing new trade skills to earn income.
3. 70% of beneficiaries report higher levels of self confidence when learning a new trade. 1. Surveys.
2. Questionnaires.
3. Organizational report.
4. Interviews with beneficiaries. Assumptions:
1. Youths trade skills and knowledge welcomed on the market.
2. Youths utilize income to pay for education or more vocational training.
Risks:
1. Unpredictable markets.
Outputs
1. Youths participating and learning trade.
2. Candles are produced and market ready.
3. Increased community involvement with youths.
 1. 100% of youths participating are initiating the candle making process.
2. 70% of the youths have successfully made quality candles ready for the market.
3. 60% youths are interacting with the community, establishing networks for their candles. 1. Organizational reports.
2. Interviews with beneficiaries.
 Assumptions:
1. Beneficiaries successfully apply knowledge and skills gained in workshops.
2. Tendency for beneficiaries to turn to trade work instead of crime.
Risks:
1. Youths may use income for the purchase of illegal substances.
2. Youths could be targeted and robbed.
Activities
1.Buy Materials to make candles
2. Candle Workshops
3.Candle Making
4. Selling candles 1. Budget = 1,869,000
2. Buy raw materials for market friendly items.
3. Setup candle workshops for youths.
4. Setup Market network to distribute product. 1. Organizational reports.

 Assumptions:
1. Youths are willing to participate.
2. Funding is provided to establish the program.
3. Community members willing to participate and help teach youths.
Risks:
Materials could be stolen.

lenders.name: Kylie
lenders.loan_because: I want to do something to make a difference in the lives of people.

lenders.name: Nancy Nyasha
lenders.loan_because: I loan because i need the start-up cost to buy software and material required to create personalised books for young children. The start up cost will also enable me to join the Create-a-Book World wide program and become one of their dearlers. I strongly believe in this business and have a passion for books and reading. It is my dream to spread and instill the culture of reading in every young Zimbabwean. Therefore this loan will enable me to start off my dream bussiness.
lenders.occupational_info:
The Create-a-Book bussiness has an impact on both young and old, for the books not only intertain but educate young children. The stories teach young readers sharing and moral values. The books motivate young children to read as they are the main characters or heros of their own stories. Above all the books will encourage young people in Zimbabwe to adopt the culture of readin. This bussiness has a positive impact  on youth who are tommorrow's leaders. Create-a-Book's slogan "Today's Readers- Tommorrows Leaders" will be the driving force of my bussiness.

The books are personalised storybooks that weaves deatails into any one of a variety of tittles, making the child the star of their own story. The books feature, the child's name,age, three freinds' names and hometown throughout the story. The books are treasured as keep sakes for the rest of the recipient's life. This bussiness will therefore, not only encourage reading in Zimbabwe and Africa in turn. It will also create a new and empowered generation of readers

lenders.name: Paul
lenders.loan_because: I would like to help someone in a developing country.  After helping and having them repay I would enjoy visiting their business and meeting them.  I would appreciate getting to know them and emailing as the business is starting.
lenders.occupational_info: I am retired from the Computer Business. I now enjoy my family, riding by bike, sailing, camping and canoeing.

lenders.name: giovanni
lenders.loan_because: I believe this is one of the best ways to empower our neighbors, giving them opportunities to become economically independent, improve their standard of living, and alleviate poverty for themselves and their communities.
lenders.occupational_info: I am a senior Java software developer and an Italian Red Cross volunteer

lenders.name: colleen - nyc
lenders.loan_because: i can

lenders.occupational_info: We are a classroom made up a 10-year old kids.

lenders.name: Charles
lenders.loan_because: I want to help the world be a better place.

lenders.name: Robert M
lenders.loan_because:
I have personal experience with "hard work" and "struggle", with "hopes" and "dreams" -- and considerable familiarity with the frustration of "I could, if only ..."

I don't have much, but certainly enough to satisfy my needs ... and which, in itself, is a great deal "more" than the vast majority of humanity can claim.

I count my blessings daily.  And I seek to share my blessings, in my own modest and humble way, with those seeking a solution to "I could, if only..."

This is why I lend through KIVA.
lenders.occupational_info:
Boring and physical.  On the other hand, I have considerable "independence" in what I do and how I do it - which I happen to do very well.   I am able to simultaneously satisfy own (high) work standards, accomplish my employer's mission,  demonstrate to and encourage true "teamwork" amongst my fellow co-workers, and provide a useful/helpful "service" to others (our customers).

Though my occupation may be "lowly", it does provide a number of "rewards" that I find personally gratifying - not the least of which is consistently "exceeding the expectations" of both my employer and (especially) my customers.

lenders.name: ERIC
lenders.loan_because: I need the to enable me start owe business which I have incorporate my company new left with working capital.It create job for the unemployed.
lenders.occupational_info: It is an entire distribution and wholesale of fast moving consumerable goods

lenders.name: LeeAnn
lenders.loan_because: I want to help others.

lenders.name: Ron
lenders.loan_because: I have been lucky in my life.  Others have not had the same opportunities as I have and I may be able to give someone a little help.
lenders.occupational_info: I gather information from the different divisions of my company for analysis and distribution to management personnel.

lenders.name: David
lenders.loan_because: If anyone has material possessions and sees his brother in need but has no pity on him, how can the love of God be in him?

lenders.name: Rebecca
lenders.loan_because: It helps me realize that I am very fortunate to have everything that I do and it allows me to share that happiness (that I am so lucky to be blessed with) with others across the globe. At the end of the day, it puts a little perk in my step knowing that someone can better their lifestyle because of a small charitable donation.
lenders.occupational_info: I am a full-time student in college and currently do not have to work outside of school. I am working on a degree in Biology, and only have about two semesters left until I graduate. I then plan on either going to medical school or veterinary technician school. And if I can muster, after that I will go back and get my Master's and possibly a Doctorate. If I do go back, I will probably get my degree in the field of Microbiology or Genetics/Forensic Anthropology.

lenders.name: Kpj  &  Assoc  Team
lenders.loan_because:
HELLO FUTURE MEMBER,
I WANTED TO LET YOU KNOW ABOUT https://www.kiva.org A
NON-PROFIT THAT ALLOWS YOU TO LEND AS LITTLE  AS  $25
TO  A  SPECIFIC  LOW-INCOME  INDIVIDUAL  INTERESTED  IN 
WORKING TOGETHER TO BUILD A SUCCESSFUL BUSINESS AND
PROSPEROUS  FINANCIAL FUTURE IN A YOU AND  ME WORLD
BELIEF SYSTEM
lenders.occupational_info:
AS AN INDEPENDENT PRODUCT CONSULTANT http://www.kiva.org IS
THE RIGHT BUSINESS,WITH THE RIGHT PRODUCT, AT THE RIGHT TIME! WE WORK WITH YOU, NOT JUST YOU, MAKING SMALL LOANS,
HELPING ORDINARY PEOPLE DISCOVER FINANCIAL REWARDS.
REFER TO www.kiva.org AND Kpj Assoc Team TO LEARN HOW!
